items.title: US music subscriptions cross 100 million as digital downloads drop
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
• Music streaming services in the US surpassed 100 million subscribers in 2024, according to RIAA's revenue report.
• Overall revenue from paid subscriptions and ad-supported services reached $14.9 billion, a 4% increase from the previous year.
• Vinyl sales continue to grow, surpassing CDs for the third consecutive year with $1.4 billion in revenue, while digital downloads dropped by 14.9%.

items.title: Nvidia says ‘the age of generalist robotics is here’
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Nvidia announced the availability of Isaac GR00T N1, an open-source, customizable foundation model for humanoid robots.
- CEO Jensen Huang stated, "The age of generalist robotics is here," highlighting advancements in AI-driven robot development.
- The framework allows robotics developers to create more adaptable and capable robots, focusing on human-robot companionship rather than mere tool functionality.
- Demonstrations included 1X’s NEO Gamma robot performing autonomous tasks using the GR00T N1 model.
- Early users of GR00T N1 include Boston Dynamics, Agility Robotics, and Neura Robotics.
- The model features a dual-system architecture: System 1 for quick reflexive actions and System 2 for reasoning and planning actions based on environmental understanding.
- Developers can customize the GR00T N1 model using data from human demonstrations or simulations, with downloadable training data available on Hugging Face and GitHub.

items.title: Nvidia’s RTX Pro 6000 has 96GB of VRAM and 600W of power
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Nvidia announces the RTX Pro Blackwell series of GPUs, including the RTX Pro 6000 for workstations.
- RTX Pro 6000 features 96GB of GDDR7 memory and requires 600W of power.
- It supports PCIe Gen 5 and DisplayPort 2.1, with enhanced RT cores and Tensor cores.
- Designed for professionals in game development and AI workloads, with variants in Max-Q and server editions.
- Pricing for the RTX Pro 6000 is not yet set; it will be available in April through partners like PNY and TD Synnex, with manufacturer availability in May.
- Cloud service providers will offer the server variant later this year, with the rest of the RTX Pro Blackwell lineup available in summer.

items.title: Nvidia's New AI Supercomputers: DGX Spark and DGX Station Revealed
items.author: Umar Shakir
items.summary:
- Nvidia launched DGX Spark and DGX Station personal AI supercomputers at GTC conference.
- DGX Spark, previously called Digits, will be available for preorder at $3,000.
- Designed for large AI model work, the DGX Station's price is unannounced but is geared toward AI developers and researchers.
- DGX Spark features GB10 Blackwell Superchip with 128GB memory and can perform up to 1,000 trillion operations per second.
- DGX Station boasts 20 petaflops of AI performance, using the new GB300 Blackwell Ultra chip.
- Collaborations with Asus, Dell, HP, and others for custom versions of the DGX supercomputers are set for release this summer.

items.title: JD Vance tries to mend the MAGA-Tech divide
items.author: Tina Nguyen
items.summary:
- JD Vance acknowledges tension between the MAGA right and tech billionaires at the American Dynamism policy conference.
- He calls for a truce between these factions within the Republican party.
- Vance seeks to reconcile the populist views against tech globalization, advocating for a united front against a common enemy - the government.

items.title: Oracle is reportedly in the lead to save TikTok from US ban
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Oracle is negotiating a deal to ensure TikTok's security in exchange for a minor stake in its US operations.
- The agreement may include guarantees preventing a backdoor access for the Chinese government.
- Concerns remain about TikTok’s algorithm potentially staying under the control of its parent company, ByteDance.
- Previous efforts, known as Project Texas, aimed to address security issues but faced skepticism from US authorities.
- A deadline is approaching, with Vice President JD Vance suggesting a high-level agreement to resolve national security concerns by April 5th.

items.title: Nvidia announces Blackwell Ultra GB300 and Vera Rubin, its next AI ‘superchips’
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- Nvidia announces two new AI chips: Blackwell Ultra GB300 and Vera Rubin.
- Blackwell Ultra GB300 expected to ship in the second half of 2025, while Vera Rubin is set for 2026 and Rubin Ultra for 2027.
- Blackwell Ultra offers 20 petaflops of AI performance with 288GB of HBM3e memory.
- a Blackwell Ultra DGX GB300 cluster features 288 CPUs, 576 GPUs, and 11.5 exaflops of FP4 computing.
- New chips aim to provide improved performance over previous models, with Vera Rubin claiming up to 50 petaflops of FP4.
- Nvidia's founder emphasizes the increasing demand for computing power, predicting the industry will need "100 times more than then we thought we needed this time last year."

items.title: Democratic FCC Commissioner Geoffrey Starks will resign this spring
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- FCC Commissioner Geoffrey Starks announced his resignation, effective spring 2024.
- Starks' departure may enable a Republican majority on the commission prior to Senate confirmation of Olivia Trusty.
- His resignation cuts his term short, which was originally set to expire in 2027.
- Starks expressed that serving as a Commissioner was the honor of his life, highlighting the importance of listening to the American people.

items.title: Microsoft’s Xbox Adaptive Joystick is now available
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- The Xbox Adaptive Joystick is designed for players with limited mobility and is now available for purchase through Microsoft’s online store for $29.99.
- It was announced at the Microsoft Ability Summit on March 18, 2025, after being initially revealed in August 2024 with a planned early 2025 release.
- Key features include customizable buttons, 3D printable accessories, four remappable buttons, an Xbox thumbstick, and compatibility with Microsoft's Adaptive Controller.

items.title: Our five favorite dunks from Drake’s label over his ‘Not Like Us’ lawsuit
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Universal Music Group (UMG) responds to Drake's lawsuit claiming defamation from Kendrick Lamar's diss track "Not Like Us."
- UMG argues that Drake's lawsuit should be dismissed as he is a "sore loser" in a rap battle.
- Drake previously signed a letter opposing the use of his lyrics in criminal cases, highlighting irony in his current lawsuit.
- UMG points out the expectation of aggressive lyrics in the context of the diss track due to prior exchanges between the artists.
- UMG counters allegations that "Not Like Us" called for violence and claims Drake's own lyrics are equally harsh.
- UMG states that controversies referenced in "Not Like Us" were already well-known and publicly documented.
- UMG disputes Drake's claims of manipulated streaming through bots and payola, calling them unsupported and speculative.

items.title: Chip race: Microsoft, Meta, Google, and Nvidia battle it out for AI chip supremacy
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Intel is testing its 18A chip process again after previous failures, involving both Nvidia and Broadcom.
- Nvidia's upcoming AI chip, Blackwell Ultra, will be announced at its GTC keynote on March 18 and expected to launch in the second half of the year.
- OpenAI plans to launch its in-house AI chip next year, produced by TSMC using advanced 3-nanometer technology.
- Intel is canceling its Falcon Shores chip and focusing resources on Jaguar Shores instead.
- Nvidia's market cap fell by almost $600 billion following competition from DeepSeek, a new Chinese AI startup.
- An antitrust investigation has been opened in China regarding Nvidia's acquisition of Mellanox after concerns over compliance with previous commitments.

items.title: GM taps Nvidia to boost its embattled self-driving projects
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Nvidia partners with GM at its annual GTC conference to develop advanced automotive technologies.
- GM will utilize Nvidia’s Omniverse and AI training software for robotics and manufacturing efficiency.
- Enhanced vehicles will feature Nvidia’s Drive AGX system-on-a-chip for autonomous capabilities and high-performance compute.
- GM's past efforts with autonomous vehicles have faced challenges and funding cuts following safety concerns.
- Nvidia expects its automotive sector to grow significantly despite current low penetration in vehicle markets.
- This partnership adds GM to a growing list of automakers collaborating with Nvidia.

items.title: Wait, why is the White House using Starlink to ‘improve Wi-Fi’?
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- The White House aims to improve Wi-Fi connectivity using Starlink due to poor cell service and strained Wi-Fi infrastructure.
- Starlink service is being piped from a government data center rather than being installed directly.
- Critics question the necessity of using Starlink when simpler solutions could suffice, and there are concerns about ethics and security.

items.title: Assassin’s Creed Shadows finally showed me the appeal of Ubisoft’s tentpole franchise
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary: - Assassin’s Creed Shadows brings the franchise to Japan after 20 years and 13 mainline games. - The game revives the dual protagonist system from Assassin’s Creed Syndicate, featuring characters Naoe and Yasuke. - Players can switch between Naoe, a stealth character, and Yasuke, a bruiser, after initial gameplay hours. - The narrative follows Naoe’s quest for vengeance and Yasuke’s journey to find his place as a samurai. - Combat systems are simple, with both characters offering distinct styles suited to different gameplay approaches. - Ubisoft focuses on detailed recreations of Japan’s historical era and cultural elements within the game world. - Shadows will launch on March 20th for Xbox, PlayStation, and PC.

items.title: Analogue’s 4K Nintendo 64 retro console has been delayed, again
items.author: Richard Lawler
items.summary:
- The Analogue 3D console's release has been delayed to "by July 2025."
- Originally scheduled for 2024, then Q1 2025.
- It will retail for $249.99 and is designed for 4K output and Bluetooth controller support.
- Analogue assures a 100% refund policy on canceled pre-orders.
- Competing product teaser by ModRetro has surfaced amid the delay.

items.title: HP’s Omen 16 Slim Gaming Laptop Features RTX 5070 GPU
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- HP introduces the Omen 16 Slim, a 16-inch gaming laptop with a thickness of 20mm (0.79 inches).
- The laptop is designed for midrange specs, featuring an Nvidia RTX 5070 GPU.
- Expected to launch in June without finalized pricing.
- It includes a 16-inch display with a 2560 x 1600 resolution, 240Hz refresh rate, and 3ms response time.
- Powered by Intel's Arrow Lake CPUs, with configurations ranging from Core Ultra 5 225H to Core Ultra 9 285H.
- Storage starts at 512GB, and RAM at 16GB.
- Weighs 5.4 pounds, still portable but not the thinnest on the market compared to competitors like Razer's Blade 16.
- It features a variety of ports, including USB-C with Power Delivery, USB-A ports, ethernet, HDMI 2.1, and Wi-Fi 6E support.
- Other models in the Omen line expected to be refreshed alongside the 16 Slim, including Omen 17 and Victus 15.

items.title: HP Launches 18 New OmniBook Models including Ultra-Light Aero
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- HP introduces 18 new OmniBook productivity laptop models across various lines including OmniBook 3, 5, 7, and X.
- Notable model: HP OmniBook 7 Aero, weighing 2.2 pounds with AMD Ryzen AI 7 350 capabilities and options for up to 1TB SSD and 32GB RAM.
- Ports include two USB-C (10Gbps), two USB-A, HDMI 2.1, and a 3.5mm audio jack, alongside a display option of either 1920 x 1200 or 2560 x 1600 resolution.
- HP is experimenting with lattice-less keyboard designs in some models, while also refreshing 20 EliteBook models emphasizing local AI capabilities.

items.title: Every gaming headset should have a backup mic like the new Cloud III S Wireless
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- HyperX announces the Cloud III S Wireless gaming headset with Bluetooth 5.3 and an additional backup microphone for calls.
- Offers up to 200 hours of battery life in Bluetooth mode and 120 hours with 2.4GHz wireless.
- Features a removable boom mic and a hidden omni-directional mic for versatile use.
- Includes magnetic earcup covers allowing customization with different designs.
- Same specifications as the Cloud III, including 53mm drivers and cushy earcups for comfort.
- Launch expected in May, pricing details yet to be finalized but similar to the previous model starting at around $150.

items.title: The first new Pebble smartwatches are coming later this year
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- Eric Migicovsky is launching two new Pebble smartwatches through his new company, Core Devices.
- The first watch is called the Core 2 Duo, priced at $149, set to ship in July with over 30 days of battery life.
- The second model, Core Time 2, will ship in December for $225 and features a touchscreen.
- Both models retain key features from older Pebble watches and emphasize long battery life and customization.
- Challenges remain with manufacturing, software integration, and connecting with iPhones.

items.title: Google's Gemini gets conversational coding and an AI podcast maker
items.author: Kylie Robison
items.summary:
- Google has released two new features for its Gemini AI assistant: Canvas and Audio Overviews.
- Canvas provides a workspace for creating and editing documents and code in real-time, with live previews for coding projects.
- The Audio Overview feature turns written content into a podcast-style discussion between two AI hosts, currently available only in English.
- These features are rolling out globally for Gemini and Gemini Advanced subscribers.
- Competitors like Anthropic and OpenAI have launched similar features, with naming conventions leading to competitive overlaps.

items.title: Satellite Launch Kicks Off New Effort to Monitor Wildfires from Space
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- A prototype satellite was launched as part of the Google-backed initiative FireSat to detect wildfires from space.
- This is the first of at least 50 satellites planned for the FireSat constellation, developed by the Earth Fire Alliance and Muon Space.
- The project received $13 million from Google.org and support from Google Research team.
- FireSat aims to provide early detection of fires as small as 5 x 5 meters, outperforming previous satellites that needed fires to grow to two acres.
- The first launch occurred at Vandenberg Space Force Base in California on March 14th, with three additional satellites planned for 2026 and full operational capacity expected by 2030.

items.title: NASA’s Crew-10 mission lifts off as the Starliner astronauts prepare to come home
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 mission launched on March 14, 2025, successfully sending astronauts to the ISS.
- Astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, stranded on the ISS for nine months, will return on the Crew-9 capsule.
- The return is scheduled for March 19, following delays due to Starliner spacecraft issues.
- The Crew-10 mission is critical in reuniting the stranded astronauts with the Earth after prolonged stay due to thruster and helium leak issues.

items.title: Lego announces Pokémon sets are coming next year
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Lego has announced that Pokémon building sets will be released in 2026.
- Specific details regarding the sets and characters are yet to be revealed, but Pikachu's tail is hinted at in the teaser.
- Previous Pokémon building sets were available through Mattel’s Mega line, but it’s unclear if Lego will have exclusivity in the future.

items.title: Nanoleaf’s new immersive backlight kit plugs directly into your PC
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Nanoleaf has released a new PC Screen Mirror Lightstrip with 75 color-changing LEDs.
- The lightstrip plugs directly into a PC's USB port and requires no additional hardware.
- Available for preorder for $49.99, shipping expected by end of March 2025.
- Designed for monitors up to 32 inches, with a flexible adhesive design for easy installation.
- Allows users to choose from 16 million colors through the desktop app, can mirror gameplay colors, and serve as an audio visualizer.
- Features integration with Nanoleaf Premium subscription for advanced music sync capabilities.

items.title: Hundreds of celebrities warn against letting OpenAI and Google ‘freely exploit’ Hollywood
Switch 2, Steam Deck, and the next-gen console wars
One of the Wii U’s biggest adventures is now on the Switch
items.author: Andrew Webster
items.summary:
- The Switch benefits from Wii U’s failure as many inventive games are being ported.
- The latest addition is *Xenoblade Chronicles X*, which initially launched in 2015.
- The game features an expansive, unexplored world called Mira, home to various alien wildlife.
- Players settle and explore with missions that enhance map details similar to *Zelda* mechanics.
- The gameplay includes real-time battles and complex systems, requiring patience and strategy to succeed.
- *Xenoblade Chronicles X* is set to launch on the Switch on March 20th, 2025.

items.title: Google acquires cybersecurity firm Wiz for $32 billion
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Google’s parent company, Alphabet, announced its largest-ever acquisition, buying cybersecurity firm Wiz for $32 billion.
- This acquisition marks Google’s second attempt after previous talks stalled at a $23 billion valuation last year.
- Wiz is a fast-growing startup known for providing cloud-based cybersecurity solutions and was valued at $12 billion in May 2024, rising to $16 billion later that year.
- If approved, the acquisition will surpass Google's 2012 purchase of Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion.
- Wiz’s products will remain available on competitor platforms, addressing potential antitrust concerns.
- Google faces ongoing antitrust lawsuits and is looking to strengthen its cloud security through this acquisition, following prior purchases of cybersecurity firms Siemplify and Mandiant.

items.title: Trump’s first 100 days: all the news affecting the tech industry
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Trump made headlines during his first 100 days, impacting the tech industry significantly.
- Protests against Tesla dealerships led to Trump proposing a media moment involving Tesla.
- A judge ordered the reinstatement of terminated probationary employees at the CFPB in response to layoffs after Musk’s agency involvement.

items.title: How Trump and Musk built their own reality
items.author: Elizabeth Lopatto
items.summary:
- Donald Trump made a sales pitch for Tesla during a public appearance in front of the White House, standing next to Elon Musk.
- Protests against Tesla dealerships highlighted the growing resentment towards Musk, who has been perceived as an unelected leader.
- Spectacle has become a defining feature of the Trump era, as media blurs the line between reality and representation.
- The prevalence of conspiracy theories among Trump supporters reflects a fundamental disconnect with reality.
- Both Trump and Musk are experts in creating media spectacles, utilizing their respective platforms to gain influence and maintain power.
- Trump’s focus on television ratings has dictated many of his actions and decisions, often at the expense of effective governance.
- Musk's online behavior, including his tweets, plays a significant role in shaping public perception and market dynamics.
- The political landscape has shifted toward prioritizing entertainment value over factual reporting, as exemplified by networks like Fox News.
- Trump's administration has struggled economically, leading to significant impacts on consumer confidence and market stability.

items.title: Bumble is getting ID verification
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Bumble is rolling out optional ID verification, providing badges for users who confirm their identity with government-issued ID.
- The ID verification requires a passport or driver’s license, along with a selfie, and is currently available in 11 markets, including the US and UK.
- A new feature called Share Date allows users to share date plans with trusted contacts and update them through the app.
- Bumble will now alert users when sending messages that may violate community guidelines, assisting in promoting safer communication.
- These new features reflect similar capabilities offered by Tinder, which launched ID verification in Japan in 2019 and fully implemented it last year.

items.title: BYD announces charging tech that’s twice as fast as Tesla’s
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- BYD reveals fast-charging technology capable of adding 400 km (249 miles) of range in just five minutes.
- New tech, known as the “Super e-Platform,” can charge at peak speeds of 1,000kW, double that of Tesla's upcoming V4 superchargers.
- Initially available in the Han L sedan and Tang L SUV, starting at 270,000 yuan (approximately $37,330).
- BYD plans to build over 4,000 ultra-fast chargers across China to support this new tech.
- The goal is to eliminate charging anxiety by reducing electric vehicle charging times to match petrol refueling times.
- BYD has sold 1.76 million cars in 2024, closely competing with Tesla's 1.79 million sales, mainly in China.

items.title: Here are the best Apple Watch deals right now
items.author: Brandon Widder
items.summary:
- Apple launched the Apple Watch Series 10 and Ultra 2 in September 2023.
- The Series 10 features improved display, S10 chip, and new sensors, priced starting at $299.99 ($100 off).
- Series 9 also available starting at $279.99 ($120 off).
- The latest SE model starts at $199, reflecting minor upgrades from the previous version.
- Discounts on the Ultra 2 start at $734.89, with various band options available.
- Each model offers substantial savings, promoting current deals across major retailers including Amazon and Walmart.

items.title: CFPB workers are reinstated after a court order, but many still can’t work
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) reinstated terminated probationary employees after a judge’s order.
- Approximately 70 probationary employees were terminated in February; the agency is required to restore them.
- Reinstated employees are still on administrative leave and cannot return to work until further notice.
- Employees will receive backpay from the date of termination, but their official files will not show a termination record.
- The CFPB headquarters remains closed, and some employees lack access to necessary systems and equipment.
- Ongoing union disputes claim attempts by the Trump administration to downsize the CFPB, which previously had about 1,700 employees.

items.title: AI search is starting to kill Google’s ‘ten blue links’
items.author: Kylie Robison
items.summary:
- Consumers are shifting from Google's traditional search format to AI chatbots for searching.
- Adobe's research shows AI search referrals increased 1,300% during 2024's holiday season compared to 2023.
- Engagement metrics indicate AI search users stay longer on sites, browse more pages, and are less likely to bounce.
- Google's generative AI search (AI Overviews) had several issues since its launch, including inaccuracies and user confusion.
- Perplexity, a startup offering AI search, has faced plagiarism controversies alongside notable financial valuation.
- OpenAI launched its AI search feature in ChatGPT, focusing on reducing weird outputs and emphasizing publisher control.
- A survey revealed that 39% of respondents use AI search for shopping, 55% for research, and 47% for recommendations.
- Concerns have been raised about traditional search being cluttered with ads and spam, prompting interest in AI search as a solution.

items.title: Roku Tests Customer Patience with New Video Ads Before Accessing Home Screen
items.author: Chris Welch
items.summary:
- Roku device users reported autoplaying video ads before accessing the homescreen, starting with a trailer for *Moana 2*.
- Customer reaction has been largely negative, with users expressing frustration over the new advertising method.
- Roku CEO Anthony Wood emphasized the need to balance ad revenue with customer satisfaction in their homescreen design.
- The company continues to explore how to integrate more dynamic advertising while maintaining a positive user experience.

items.title: All the news about daily puzzle games
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Puzzmo aims to enhance newspaper games pages.
- The New York Times revamped its crossword app for a better gaming experience.
- The Spelling Bee puzzle celebrates its 2,500th edition with a themed challenge on the NYT app.
- Samsung's trivia game, The Six, now available on Galaxy phones, involves daily challenge formats.
- A Connections puzzle creator shut down due to a DMCA notice from the NYT.
- NYT tech workers created strike-themed games as alternatives during their strike.
- Words With Friends introduces daily single-player puzzles that mimic NYT's styles.
- Netflix is launching TED Tumblewords, a daily word game for subscribers on November 19.

items.title: Amazon is fighting the government’s efforts to get it to recall hazardous products
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
• Amazon is suing the US Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) over its responsibility to recall hazardous products sold on its marketplace.
• CPSC previously claimed Amazon failed to recall dangerous items, prompting legal action in 2021.
• Amazon argues it is a logistics provider and thus not obligated to carry out recalls as a distributor would be, calling the CPSC’s structure unconstitutional.
• In 2023, Amazon launched a product recall page, but continues to contest its legal obligations.

items.title: Google has a fix for all of the broken Chromecasts
items.author: Umar Shakir
items.summary:
- Google started rolling out an update on Thursday to fix Chromecasts that lost the ability to cast.
- The new update addresses issues with Chromecast devices that were bricked after a factory reset.
- Affected owners received confirmation from Google that everything should function normally now.
- The update includes a new Google Home app version (3.30.1.6 for Android, 3.30.106 for iOS) to revive broken Chromecast devices.
- The exact cause of the issues was not disclosed, but it may be linked to an expired certificate according to user findings.
- The rollout of the new app update began recently and may take a few days to reach all users.

items.title: Mark Rober’s Tesla Video: Controversy and Analysis
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Mark Rober's video compares Tesla’s Autopilot with lidar-equipped vehicles by testing their braking before hitting a wall.
- The Tesla Model Y crashed into the wall while the lidar vehicle stopped successfully.
- The video garnered 10 million views in two days, praised for exposing Autopilot's shortcomings but also criticized for possible deception.
- Several claims from viewers suggest inconsistencies in the video, questioning whether Autopilot was active during the test.
- Rober released raw footage showing Autopilot was engaged moments before the crash, but critics argue it disengaged right before impact.
- Concerns have been raised regarding Rober's potential sponsorship by lidar company Luminar due to its prominent branding in the video.
- Rober denied any compensation from Luminar, claiming it was not a paid promotion.

items.title: Perplexity dunks on Google’s ‘glue on pizza’ AI fail in new ad
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Perplexity launches a new ad featuring Squid Game star Lee Jung-jae.
- The ad humorously references a Google AI error suggesting using glue to make cheese stick to pizza.
- Google’s AI Overviews have faced criticism for inaccuracies, including the controversial glue advice.
- Perplexity positions itself as a viable alternative to Google’s AI offerings, facing its own allegations of content plagiarism.

items.title: A sodium-ion portable power bank comes to market
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Elecom introduces the first consumer-ready sodium-ion power bank, the Na Plus, with a capacity of 9,000mAh.
- The Na Plus is claimed to last up to 5,000 charges and can operate in extreme temperatures from -30 to 122°F.
- Priced at 9,980 yen (around $67), it is debuting in Japan with no current plans for wider rollout.
- The power bank features 45W output through USB-C and 18W through USB-A, taking about two hours to fully charge.
- Sodium-ion technology is seen as more environmentally friendly and safer than lithium-ion, though it is bulkier and heavier due to lower energy density.

items.title: Great savings on the EcoFlow Delta Pro 3, which will keep your home powered
items.author: Barbara Krasnoff
items.summary:
- EcoFlow is offering discounts on its portable batteries and power stations through March 26th.
- The Delta Pro 3 power station is currently priced at $2,899, a $700 reduction from its usual price of $3,699.
- The Delta Pro 3 can power 120V and 240V appliances, charge via solar or AC, and multiple units can be linked for more power.
- EcoFlow's River 3 Portable Power Station is also on sale for $189, ideal for camping and outdoor use.

items.title: The entire story of Twitter / X under Elon Musk
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- X will start charging new users in two countries $1 per year.
- Users reporting smaller than expected ad revenue sharing payments.
- Elon Musk seeks a second chance with X after his previous failures.
- The extravagant ‘X’ sign atop the former Twitter HQ has been dismantled.
- ‘For Elon Musk, X equals everything’ as his vision expands.
- Instagram challenges Twitter with its new Threads app.
- X's ad revenue sharing model under scrutiny amid performance concerns.
- A significant cyberattack claimed by Musk during an outage affecting hundreds of thousands of users.
- A Twitter logo from the prior HQ is up for auction amidst the rebranding effort.

items.title: US Tariffs: How Trump’s Tax is Impacting Big Tech and Beyond
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
* President Trump has imposed tariffs on goods imported from Mexico, Canada, and China.
* Big Tech companies have mostly remained silent on the potential impact of these tariffs on their operations.
* Automakers are expected to face significant consequences from Trump’s tariffs, which include a 25% tax on imports from Mexico and Canada, effective immediately.
* Companies like Lego, BMW, and Foxconn have commented on how tariffs will affect pricing and supply chains.
* Target and Best Buy CEOs indicated that prices for consumers may rise due to the tariffs primarily affecting products from Mexico.

items.title: Big Tech is now slightly less silent on Trump’s tariffs
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- President Trump’s tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada, and China are now in effect, largely unopposed by Big Tech.
- Companies like Walmart express commitment to keeping prices low while CEOs from Best Buy and Target predict imminent price increases.
- Gigabyte and Framework discuss potential price adjustments, while many other major companies remain silent or decline to comment.
- The Trump administration may alter tariffs, with a recent temporary exemption announced for automotive tariffs on Canada and Mexico.
- Long-term effects of tariffs on tech product pricing remain uncertain until major launches occur.

items.title: Pixel 9A leaks in review videos before it’s even announced
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Leaked videos of the Pixel 9A have surfaced before its official announcement.
- YouTubers Sahil Karoul and The Mobile Central showcase the phone's design and performance.
- The Pixel 9A features a flat back design, a 6.3-inch display, and a 5,100mAh battery.
- Camera specs include a 48-megapixel main sensor, 13-megapixel ultrawide, and 13-megapixel selfie camera; video quality is subpar at night.
- Expected reveal date is March 19th, with various color options including purple, pink, black, and white.

items.title: Snap’s AR Spectacles now support a virtual keyboard and GPS
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Snap's Spectacles now feature GPS for navigation and improved hand tracking.
- An AR keyboard allows for text entry without a connected smartphone.
- New AR capabilities include location-based gaming and walking course development for users.
- Spectacles remain developer-only, requiring a $99 monthly rental commitment for at least a year.

items.title: Trump claims Biden pardons are ‘void’ due to autopen usage
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Trump asserts that some of Biden's pardons are void because they were allegedly signed using an autopen.
- He claims that Biden was unaware of the pardons, citing a post on Truth Social.
- Critics point out that Trump's claims lack evidence, and Biden has publicly addressed the pardons.
- Autopen usage by presidents has historical precedent, with past presidents like Ford and Obama using them for signing documents.
- The Justice Department has previously indicated there is no legally prescribed method for executive clemency signature.

items.title: Max just wiped its classic Looney Tunes lineup
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Warner Bros. Discovery removed the entire lineup of classic Looney Tunes shorts (1930-1969) from its streaming service, Max.
- The company confirmed the focus will shift to adult and family programming rather than kids' content.
- This follows earlier removals of Looney Tunes episodes at the end of 2022 and confusion over the series' availability.
- Newer Looney Tunes content remains available on Max.
- This content purge is part of broader cuts following David Zaslav's takeover of Warner Bros. Discovery.
- Max had also ended its streaming deal for Sesame Street and made notable content changes under the new administration.
